Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Symposium on Thermal Deconstruction of Biomass

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is to support a one-day mini-symposium on November 1, 2017, which will be held in conjunction with the AIChE Annual Meeting in Minneapolis, MN. The objective of this mini-symposium is to create a unique environment to allow the interactions of prominent researchers who work in the field of thermal deconstruction of biomass materials for producing novel biorenewable fuels. This mini-symposium will feature three sessions of invited speakers and a poster reception, featuring relevant research of graduate students. The three oral sessions, each consisting of talks by five invited speakers are: 1) Pathways to thermal deconstruction, 2) Fundamentals of thermal deconstruction, and 3) Upgrading products from thermal deconstruction. The funding will partially support the participation of the fifteen invited speakers and the young scientists presenting at the poster reception.

Thermal deconstruction is an intriguing new approach to fractionating lignocellulose biomass into components suitable for upgrading into biobased products. The use of heat to fractionate and depolymerize plant biopolymers into solubilized carbohydrate and lignin-derived phenolic monomers has often been overlooked or even dismissed in the field of biofuels and biobased products. Its practitioners often self-segregate because they fail to recognize commonalities among the phenomena they study. Even less common are interactions and collaborations among those who thermally deconstruct biomass and those who depend upon deconstructed biomass as substrates for bioprocessing. To date, there has been no forum to bring together researchers who are pioneering thermal deconstruction as well as those who seek new sources of bioprocessing substrates. This mini-symposium will provide an excellent opportunity to bring experts together to address this important research field, which will have a significant impact on the development of the renewable energy technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Thermal deconstruction is an intriguing new approach to fractionating lignocellulose biomass into components suitable for upgrading into a wide variety of biobased products.  The objective of this project was to organize and host an event where scientists and engineers working at the forefront of this nascent research area would come together to share ideas and challenges, network with the diverse people affiliated with AIChE, and interface with students to educate and recruit the next generation of scientists and engineers.  

The American Institute of Chemical Engineers is the premier professional society for chemical engineers, with over 60,000 members from over 110 different countries. The AIChE Annual Meeting is the largest gathering of chemical engineers in the world, attracting over 5,000 professionals from industry and academia, with over 750 technical sessions covering a very wide range of topics of importance to the broad areas of chemical engineering.

In keeping with this theme, the Thermal Deconstruction of Biomass Topical Conference took place during the 2017 AIChE Annual Meeting in Minneapolis, MN. Over the course of this Meeting, more than 5,650 attendees from all 50 U.S. states and 54 countries were exposed to technical programming in this area.

The mini-symposium featured three oral sessions; each with five speakers:  1) Pathways to thermal deconstruction, 2) Fundamentals of thermal deconstruction, and 3) Upgrading products from thermal deconstruction.  A poster reception featured relevant research of graduate students.  NSF provided funding to provide stipends to each of the presenters.

More than 50 scientists, engineers and students attended the mini-symposium.  Quotes from student participants included:

  • “At such a large conference like AIChE 2017, it was awesome to have so many of the leading biofuels researchers gathered for a series of technical sessions.  I was able to meet and engage with most of the presenters throughout the day and especially during the poster session/reception later in the evening.”  (Joe Polin, Graduate Student, Iowa State University"
  • "It was a captivating experience to witness so many brilliant scientists and researchers present their ideas on thermal deconstruction of biomass for producing fuels and chemicals. While some focused on solving current challenges of biomass utilization, some brought a completely fresh look at biomass processing. It was fascinating to chat with these researchers coming from prestigious institutes around the globe. The interactions not only helped me learn a lot of new and useful things about biorenewables, but also accelerated my career development." 

(Arpa Ghosh, Graduate Student, Iowa State University)


Last Modified: 07/10/2018
Modified by: Stephanie Orvoine-Couvrette
